description: Practice the meanings and usage of phrasal verbs with 'get' using definition matching questions.

questions.question: get up
questions.answer: To rise from bed or a sitting position.
questions.example: I get up at 6 AM every morning.
choices: To rise from bed or a sitting position.
To arrive or reach a destination.

questions.question: get on
questions.answer: To board a vehicle or to have a good relationship.
questions.example: I need to get on the bus before it leaves.
choices: To board a vehicle or to have a good relationship.

questions.question: get off
questions.answer: To leave a vehicle or to stop working.
questions.example: I get off work at 5 PM.
choices: To leave a vehicle or to stop working.

questions.question: get over
questions.answer: To recover from illness or overcome a problem.
questions.example: It took me weeks to get over the flu.
choices: To recover from illness or overcome a problem.

questions.question: get in
questions.answer: To enter a vehicle or building.
questions.example: Get in the car, we're late!
choices: To enter a vehicle or building.

questions.question: get out
questions.answer: To leave or exit a place.
questions.example: I need to get out of this traffic jam.
choices: To leave or exit a place.

questions.question: get away
questions.answer: To escape or go on vacation.
questions.example: I need to get away from the city for a while.
choices: To escape or go on vacation.
To leave or exit a place.

questions.question: get back
questions.answer: To return to a place or recover something.
questions.example: What time did you get back from your trip?
choices: To return to a place or recover something.
To escape or go on vacation.
To leave or exit a place.

questions.question: get through
questions.answer: To complete something or make contact.
questions.example: I finally got through all my homework.
choices: To complete something or make contact.
To escape or go on vacation.
To leave or exit a place.

questions.question: get along
questions.answer: To have a good relationship with someone.
questions.example: I get along well with my coworkers.
choices: To have a good relationship with someone.
To escape or go on vacation.

questions.question: get by
questions.answer: To manage or survive with limited resources.
questions.example: We can get by on a small budget.
choices: To manage or survive with limited resources.

questions.question: get down
questions.answer: To descend or feel depressed.
questions.example: Get down from that tree, it's dangerous!

questions.question: get into
questions.answer: To become involved in or enter something.
questions.example: I got into reading mystery novels.
choices: To become involved in or enter something.

questions.question: get around
questions.answer: To travel or move from place to place.
questions.example: It's hard to get around the city without a car.
choices: To travel or move from place to place.

questions.question: get ahead
questions.answer: To make progress or advance in life.
questions.example: Hard work will help you get ahead in your career.
choices: To make progress or advance in life.
To travel or move from place to place.

questions.question: get together
questions.answer: To meet or gather with others.
questions.example: Let's get together for dinner this weekend.
choices: To meet or gather with others.

questions.question: get rid of
questions.answer: To eliminate or throw away something.
questions.example: I need to get rid of these old clothes.
choices: To eliminate or throw away something.
To meet or gather with others.

questions.question: get used to
questions.answer: To become accustomed or familiar with something.
questions.example: It took time to get used to the new schedule.
choices: To become accustomed or familiar with something.
To eliminate or throw away something.
To meet or gather with others.

questions.question: get across
questions.answer: To communicate or convey a message clearly.
questions.example: I'm trying to get my point across to the team.
choices: To communicate or convey a message clearly.
To eliminate or throw away something.
To meet or gather with others.

questions.question: get behind
questions.answer: To fall behind schedule or support someone.
questions.example: I got behind on my work this week.
choices: To fall behind schedule or support someone.
To eliminate or throw away something.

questions.question: get hold of
questions.answer: To obtain or contact someone.
questions.example: I need to get hold of a good lawyer.

questions.question: get lost
questions.answer: To lose one's way or become confused.
questions.example: We got lost trying to find the restaurant.
choices: To lose one's way or become confused.

questions.question: get stuck
questions.answer: To become trapped or unable to move.
questions.example: The car got stuck in the mud.
choices: To become trapped or unable to move.

questions.question: get ready
questions.answer: To prepare for something.
questions.example: Get ready for school, the bus is coming!
choices: To become trapped or unable to move.

questions.question: get married
questions.answer: To join in marriage with someone.
questions.example: They got married last summer.
choices: To join in marriage with someone.
To become trapped or unable to move.

questions.question: get dressed
questions.answer: To put on clothes.
questions.example: I need to get dressed for the party.
choices: To become trapped or unable to move.

questions.question: get started
questions.answer: To begin or commence something.
questions.example: Let's get started with the meeting.

questions.question: get worse
questions.answer: To deteriorate or become more severe.
questions.example: The weather is getting worse.
choices: To deteriorate or become more severe.

questions.question: get better
questions.answer: To improve or recover.
questions.example: I hope your cold gets better soon.
choices: To deteriorate or become more severe.

questions.question: get tired
questions.answer: To become exhausted or weary.
questions.example: I get tired after working all day.
choices: To deteriorate or become more severe.

questions.question: get angry
questions.answer: To become mad or irritated.
questions.example: Don't get angry over small things.
choices: To deteriorate or become more severe.

questions.question: get excited
questions.answer: To become enthusiastic or thrilled.
questions.example: The kids got excited about the trip.

questions.question: get confused
questions.answer: To become puzzled or uncertain.
questions.example: I got confused by the instructions.

questions.question: get involved
questions.answer: To participate or become engaged in something.
questions.example: I want to get involved in community service.
choices: To participate or become engaged in something.

questions.question: get caught
questions.answer: To be discovered doing something wrong.
questions.example: He got caught cheating on the test.
choices: To be discovered doing something wrong.

questions.question: get fired
questions.answer: To be dismissed from a job.
questions.example: She got fired for being late too often.
choices: To be dismissed from a job.
To be discovered doing something wrong.

questions.question: get hired
questions.answer: To be employed or given a job.
questions.example: I got hired at the new restaurant.
choices: To be employed or given a job.
To be dismissed from a job.
To be discovered doing something wrong.

questions.question: get promoted
questions.answer: To advance to a higher position.
questions.example: She got promoted to manager last month.
choices: To advance to a higher position.
To be employed or given a job.
To be dismissed from a job.
To be discovered doing something wrong.

questions.question: get paid
questions.answer: To receive money for work.
questions.example: I get paid every two weeks.
choices: To advance to a higher position.
To be employed or given a job.
To be dismissed from a job.

questions.question: get hurt
questions.answer: To be injured or harmed.
questions.example: Be careful not to get hurt on the playground.
choices: To advance to a higher position.
To be employed or given a job.

questions.question: get sick
questions.answer: To become ill or unwell.
questions.example: I got sick after eating that food.
choices: To advance to a higher position.

questions.question: get well
questions.answer: To recover from illness.
questions.example: I hope you get well soon.

questions.question: get old
questions.answer: To age or become elderly.
questions.example: We all get old eventually.

questions.question: get dark
questions.answer: To become nighttime or lose light.
questions.example: It gets dark early in winter.
choices: To become nighttime or lose light.

questions.question: get cold
questions.answer: To become chilly or lower in temperature.
questions.example: My hands get cold in winter.
choices: To become chilly or lower in temperature.
To become nighttime or lose light.

questions.question: get hot
questions.answer: To become warm or increase in temperature.
questions.example: The room gets hot in the afternoon.
choices: To become warm or increase in temperature.
To become chilly or lower in temperature.
To become nighttime or lose light.

questions.question: get wet
questions.answer: To become soaked with water.
questions.example: Don't get wet in the rain.
choices: To become warm or increase in temperature.
To become chilly or lower in temperature.
To become nighttime or lose light.

questions.question: get dry
questions.answer: To become free of moisture.
questions.example: Hang the clothes outside to get dry.
choices: To become warm or increase in temperature.
To become chilly or lower in temperature.

questions.question: get clean
questions.answer: To become free of dirt or stains.
questions.example: I need to get clean before dinner.
choices: To become free of dirt or stains.
To become warm or increase in temperature.

questions.question: get dirty
questions.answer: To become soiled or stained.
questions.example: Kids always get dirty when they play outside.
choices: To become free of dirt or stains.

questions.question: get hungry
questions.answer: To feel the need for food.
questions.example: I get hungry around lunchtime.
choices: To feel the need for food.
To become free of dirt or stains.

questions.question: get thirsty
questions.answer: To feel the need for drink.
questions.example: I get thirsty after exercising.
choices: To feel the need for drink.
To feel the need for food.
To become free of dirt or stains.

title: Phrasal Verbs With Get
